Project Description  The Project will produce the following outputs: (i) rehabilitation and 
improvement of about 123 kilometers (km) of core network roads; (ii) 
labor-intensive routine road maintenance on 45 km; (iii) sound and 
sustainable road maintenance policies; (iv) an efficient bidding and 
contracting  system  for  engaging  communities  in  road  maintenance 
through  local  small  contractors;  (v)  improved  project  management, 
supervision,  and  monitoring;  and  (vi)  identification  of  modalities  to 
ensure sustained rehabilitation and maintenance of rural feeder roads. 
Rationale  Timor-Leste is one of the least-developed countries in the world. Per 
capita  gross  domestic  product  was  estimated  at  $405  in  2004. 
Officially, more than 40% of the population is reported to live under 
$0.55 per day, the national poverty line. However, according to the 
estimates of Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance for 
Transport Sector Improvement, poverty prevalence is likely as high as 
88%, and approximately 46% of the population live in absolute poverty. 
During  the  1999  conflict,  most  communication  and  power  facilities 
were destroyed. In spite of some restoration efforts, postal services are 
still closed except in Baucau and Dili. The electrification ratio for all 
households  is  only  20%;  95%  of  rural  households  are  without 
electricity. About 48% of the population does not have access to safe 
water supply, and 69% does not have access to adequate sanitation 
facilities. Access to health facilities remains problematic. The time and 
money costs to reach a community health center or a hospital are 
substantial.  Life  expectancy  is  low—less  than  60  years.  Currently, 
about a third of children are not enrolled in primary school; 20% of the 
enrolled  do  not  attend  classes.  More  than  half  the  population  is 
illiterate. Markets are either nonexistent or access is prevented due to 
mountainous topography, poor transport system, and lack of transport 
services. 
 
As  a  new  nation,  Timor-Leste  faces  many  challenges.  The  most 
pressing  issues  include  (i)  sustained  economic  growth,  (ii)  poverty 
reduction, (iii) employment, (iv) a legal and institutional framework to 
manage  and  administer  the  new  nation  state  and  transform  the 
agrarian subsistence production to a market-oriented economy, and (v) 
weak human and institutional capacity.

infrastructure  is  of  overarching  importance  to  all  sectors  of  the

transport system, is critical in fostering private sector development,

The Project, therefore, will focus on physical road infrastructure and its 
implementation. As a post-conflict country, Timor-Leste is eligible for

industrial and agricultural development; (iii) foster market formation 
and  facilitate  domestic  and  international  trade;  and  (iv)  generate 
income and employment opportunities. The outcome will be improved 
road infrastructure for economic and social development.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the Road Sector Improvement Project. 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Timor-Leste is a small and mountainous island country, with a population of 925,000 and 
a  land  area  of  14,609  square  kilometers.  It  is  located  at  the  eastern  end  of  the  Sunda 
archipelago and has a dramatic topography dominated by the Ramelau Mountains stretching 
across the middle of the island from the east to the west. The coastal zones in the north and 
south are narrow, and are largely on steep hillsides. 
3.  Roads provide the dominant mode of transport, carrying about 70% of freight and 90% 
of passenger traffic. The total length of the extensive road network is estimated at 6,040 
kilometers (km), comprising 1,430 km of national roads linking district centers, 870 km of district 
roads providing links to large administrative centers, and 720 km in Dili and several smaller 
regional towns. The remaining 3,020 km are rural access or feeder roads. 
4.  The extensive and dense road network was constructed with relatively low standards of 
design and materials. A pragmatic approach adapting to the often severe terrain conditions was 
used,  resulting  in  a  very  low  horizontal  and  vertical  geometrical  standard  in  mountainous 
regions. The road widths appear to have been compromised according to the actual terrain 
conditions, resulting in many very narrow roads. While 100% of national roads and 71% of 
district roads were bitumen paved, shoulders are often constructed out of impervious earthen 
material. This, combined with the difficult geological conditions, torrential rains, and lack of 
maintenance, has caused rapid deterioration of the road system. Only 24% of national roads 
and 11% of district roads are currently in good condition. 
5.  Traffic volume is small and concentrated around Dili. Traffic counts in 2000 showed that 
one third of the road network outside the urban center carried more than 200 vehicles per day 
(with 15% carrying more than 500 vehicles per day, less than 2% carrying more than 1,000 
vehicles per day). One third of the network carried less than 50 vehicles per day. Traffic counts 
in 2005 estimate the average daily traffic for motorized vehicles at about 160 on national roads, 
90 on district roads, 30 on rural roads, and 170 on urban roads. The heaviest traffic flows in 
excess of 400 vehicles per day are on the northern coastal road. 
6.  Walking is the most common mode of transportation, followed by small trucks, and 
microbuses. Transport services are mainly provided by small-scale private companies owning 
one or two vehicles, and a small number of vehicle owner-operators. The Government has set 
minimum taxi fare rates, but has not set rates for passenger and freight buses and trucks.  
7.  Drivers’  associations  are  apparently  developing  and  setting  rates.  Passenger  fares 
range from $0.50 to $3.00, depending on distance, averaging approximately $1.00 per one-way 
trip. This is high and not affordable for many rural people, particularly the poor. These rates do 
not provide a decent livelihood for vehicle operators/owners: almost half are estimated to be 
living below the national poverty line. Operating costs are high; repair costs average about 
$1,500 per year. Nearly 50% of the total repair costs are caused by the poor road conditions. 
8.  Rehabilitating and maintaining the extensive road network will incur considerable cost to 
the Government. Difficult terrain, geology, and weather conditions impose additional costs. 
Given the current level of traffic demand and state of the economy, user charges are not likely

2 
to be able to generate sufficient revenue to finance road sector development. Prioritizing and 
sequencing to maximize the benefits of investment are therefore essential. Past efforts have 
focused on basic maintenance, rehabilitation, and emergency works. The cost of this reactive 
approach was high and needs to shift to a preventive approach of gradually rehabilitating the 
system  so  that  it  can  be  sustained  with  normal  routine  and  periodic  maintenance  and  a 
manageable amount of emergency repairs. 
9.  The  Project  will  rehabilitate  and  maintain  four  crucial  roads  in  agricultural  areas  to 
promote economic and social development, and explore low-cost, community-based modalities 
for road maintenance. The design and monitoring framework is attached as Appendix 1.  
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
10.  As a post-conflict country emerging from 3 years of United Nations (UN) administration, 
Timor-Leste faces many challenges and opportunities. The most pressing include (i) sustained 
economic growth, (ii) poverty reduction, (iii) employment, (iv) a legal and institutional framework 
to  manage  and  administer  the  new  nation  state  and  transform  the  agrarian  subsistence 
production to a market-oriented economy, and (v) weak human and institutional capacity. 
1.  Problems 
11.  Economic Growth. The large influx of UN forces, bilateral and multilateral donors, 
foreign experts, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and financial aid boosted consumption 
and investment, and generated income and job opportunities. Real gross domestic product 
(GDP) growth was estimated at 18% in 2000 and 15% in 2001. But with the winding down of the 
international assistance, economic growth fell significantly in 2002 to an estimated 3%, and 
became negative in 2003 (minus 3%). Growth in 2004 was moderate at about 1%. 
12.  Poverty. Timor-Leste is one of the least-developed countries in the world, in terms of 
per capita GDP, estimated at $405 in 2004. Officially, more than 40% of the population is 
reported  to  live  below  the  national  poverty  line  of  $0.55  per  day.  However,  according  to 
estimates  of  ADB  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Transport  Sector  Improvement,1  poverty 
prevalence is likely to be as high as 88%, and approximately 46% live in absolute poverty. As 
three quarters of the population reside in rural areas, surviving on subsistence and seasonal 
agriculture,  poverty  is  predominantly  a  rural  phenomenon.  During  the  1999  conflict,  most 
communication and power facilities were destroyed. In spite of some restoration efforts, postal 
services are still closed except in Baucau and Dili. The electrification ratio for all households is 
only 20%; 95% of rural households are without electricity. About 48% of the population do not 
have access to safe water supplies, and 69% do not have access to adequate sanitation 
facilities. Access to health facilities remains a problem. The time and money costs to reach a 
community health center or a hospital are substantial (70 minutes by walking and 2 hours by 
minibus, $1 on average for one-way bus fare). Life expectancy is low, less than 60 years. While 
access to schooling improved considerably prior to 1999, the quality of teaching and learning 
was low. Currently, about a third of children are not enrolled in primary school; 20% of the 
enrolled do not attend classes. More than half of the population is illiterate. Markets are either 
nonexistent or access is prevented or severely hampered due to mountainous topography, poor 
transport system, and lack of transport services.  
13.  Employment. The total fertility rate is very high, estimated to be 8.3. Every year, about 
16,000 new workers enter the labor force. The rapid increase in population and labor force has

not been accompanied by an increase in job opportunities. Agriculture is the principal economic 
activity and the most important source of livelihood. But agricultural development is hampered 
by falling prices, deteriorating rural infrastructure, lack of rural services and access to markets, 
and traditional cultivation practices. Productivity and incomes are low. Underemployment is 
widespread. Poverty prevalence is high. People are moving to the cities, particularly the capital 
Dili, in search of job and income opportunities, which are scarce. The public sector offers little 
prospect  for  wage  employment,  due  to  the  limited  number  of  government  positions. 
Development  of  the  small  private  business  sector  is  constrained  by  poor  and  expensive 
infrastructure facilities, lack of legal and regulatory environment, devastated business services, 
and low labor productivity. Moreover, the withdrawal of expatriates is causing job losses. 
14.  Legal and Institutional Framework. Timor-Leste emerged from the conflict with large-
scale devastation. With the 1999 referendum, linkages to the Indonesian legal and institutional 
framework  were  severed.  With  international  assistance,  a  government  structure  has  taken 
shape.  Some  laws  and  regulations  have  been  promulgated.  However,  the  process  of 
introducing necessary laws and regulations is slow. The Government’s organizational structure 
is still evolving and subject to constant changes. These create risks and uncertainties for the 
private  sector  as  well  as  donor  agencies.  The  organizational  change  of  the  Ministry  of 
Transport, Communications, and Public Works, initially formed in 2002, is a good illustration. 
The Government recently split the ministry into the Ministry of Transport and Communications 
and Ministry of Public Works (MPW).  
15.  Weak Human and Institutional Capacity. The human resource base is low as a result 
of  the  conflict  and  tragedies.  Administrative,  managerial,  entrepreneurial,  technical,  and 
vocational skills are in short supply in all sectors of the economy. Middle to senior managerial 
positions are difficult to fill with qualified people. The vast majority of current civil servants are 
neither experienced nor trained for the roles they are undertaking. The Government depends 
heavily on foreign experts for daily administrative operations, policy formulation, and preparation 
and implementation of development projects. The problem is also acute in the road sector. The 
Directorate  of  Roads,  Bridges,  and  Flood  Control,  which  is  responsible  for  provision  and 
management  of  road  infrastructure,  has  only  12  staff,  of  a  total  of  91,  with  technical 
qualifications. They have limited skills in the formulation of technical standards, road planning, 
prioritization, project preparation and implementation, and asset management, and have to 
focus on managing emergency repair work. 
16.  Social, Gender, and Health-Related Issues. Difficult terrain, geology, and weather 
conditions contribute to the isolation of local communities and severely limit access to water 
supplies, energy, food, basic social services (health and education), and local markets. The 
poor conditions of rural feeder roads especially affect rural women, who are responsible for 
carrying clean water, collecting fodder and fuelwood, and marketing agriculture products. To 
ensure tangible benefits to poor and isolated communities, the rehabilitation of national roads 
should be accompanied by an increasing focus on the rehabilitation of secondary and rural 
feeder roads to ensure connectivity to markets, towns, and health and educational facilities. This 
complementary approach is likely to increase the anticipated poverty reduction impact of road 
improvement. Strengthening the capacity of local communities to prioritize and sequence their 
needs in terms of feeder road rehabilitation and maintenance contributes to the sustainability of 
road improvements. The traditional gender division of labor can be challenged by proactively 
ensuring women’s involvement in road rehabilitation and maintenance in a culturally sensitive 
manner.  Areas  identified  by  local  constructors  and  surveyed  communities  for  potential 
involvement of women include support services to construction camps and bioengineering. 
Women’s effective access to these employment opportunities will require targeted programs of 
labor  skills  transfer.  Timor-Leste  is  characterized  by  low—mostly  underreported—human

4 
immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) prevalence. Although 
data on HIV prevalence is inadequate, recent surveys jointly carried out by the Ministry of 
Health (MOH) and the World Health Organization estimate HIV prevalence of 0.64% (MOH, 
2002 HIV/AIDS summary report). The exposure of currently isolated communities to road traffic 
calls for special attention to the critical risks of HIV/AIDS and sexually transmitted infection 
(STI). In light of women’s greater exposure to the risks and impacts of HIV/AIDS, culturally 
sensitive  and  gender-responsive  HIV/AIDS  awareness  initiatives  should  be  provided  in 
campsites and corridors of influence as part of reproductive health programs. 
2.  Opportunities 
17.  National Development Plan. Following the restoration of independence in 2002, Timor-
Leste has aspired to build a more democratic and affluent society. Its vision, priorities, and 
development strategies are articulated in the National Development Plan. The plan focuses on 
two overriding development objectives: (i) to reduce poverty in all sectors and regions of the 
nation; and (ii) to promote economic growth that is equitable and sustainable, and improve the 
health,  education,  and  well-being  of  the  population.  The  Government  recognizes  that 
infrastructure is of overarching importance to all sectors of the economy and society; and that 
improving infrastructure, particularly the transport system, is critical to foster private sector 
development, improve agricultural productivity, reduce poverty, promote investment and human 
development, and strengthen the Government’s capacity to deliver services. 
18.  Sector Investment Plan. Fifteen sector investment plans, sponsored by ADB and other 
development partners, were developed during 2003–2005, covering basic services, production, 
basic infrastructure, and governance. The plans assessed the status of each sector, identified 
issues, and predicted funding requirements. The plan for transport assessed aviation, maritime, 
and land transport, but placed the emphasis on the road sector. It argued that road investment 
should receive priority over investments in airports and seaports, as most East Timorese travel 
by  road  and  the  road  network  is  prone  to  failures,  resulting  from  long-term  neglect  of 
maintenance and unfavorable topographical and weather conditions. Ports and airports were 
upgraded during earlier emergency measures, and their capacity should meet demand for the 
foreseeable future. 
19.  Government Vision for the Road Sector. The Government’s 10-year vision for the 
road system is to (i) bring the road network to a sustainable condition where, with regular 
maintenance, life-cycle costs will be minimized, road closures reduced and manageable, and 
road access reliable; (ii) improve key roads to support a growing economy; (iii) ensure effective 
capacity to manage the road system, comprising asset management systems (including risk 
management), use of the private sector for cost-effective delivery, and reliable funding and 
adequate cost-recovery from users. Priority will be given to maintaining the current roads, 
particularly  the  core  road  network  serving  major  economic  and  administrative  functions. 
Investments will focus on projects that provide net economic benefits in terms of reduced road 
maintenance  and  vehicle  operating  costs,  and  that  support  agricultural  and  industrial 
developments. 
20.  ADB Strategy. In the short term, economic growth and employment have to come from 
infrastructure  investments.  The  ADB  country  strategy  and  program  update  for  2005-20062 
identifies infrastructure development and institutional capacity building as the major areas for 
ADB  assistance.  The  Transport  Sector  Improvement  TA  (footnote  1)  was  to  assist  the 
Government in prioritizing road investments to maximize benefits and search for least-cost ways

to rehabilitate and maintain the core road system over the coming decade. Extensive surveys of 
road conditions, traffic volume, socioeconomic conditions, and the physical environment were 
undertaken.  Rigorous  economic  analyses  were  conducted.  A  prioritized  road  development 
program was proposed and will be used by the Government, ADB, and other development 
partners to plan interventions. 
21.  The Project comprises four roads located in the central and western south coast of the 
country. These two regions are agricultural areas and have potential for industrial and port 
development, and international trade, yet they are currently suffering from isolation and food 
insecurity. The Project will complement efforts of the Government of Japan and the European 
Union (EU) to (i) increase access for people in these two regions to major market centers for 
food  and  social  services;  (ii)  open  up  opportunities  for  people  to  participate  in  economic 
activities; and (iii) increase income to enhance their affordability for food and economic and 
social services. It will reduce transport costs for coffee collectors and vehicle operating costs for 
private transport service operators, thus promoting industrial and agricultural development. 
22.  In the area of institutional capacity building, ADB has approved a TA3 to develop an 
integrated institutional development road map for infrastructure sectors and a road map for road 
sector capacity building that would leverage resources from development agencies. The TA will 
address the urgent needs of the road sector by training government and private individuals to 
build their technical and contract management skills so that they can supervise the Project to 
facilitate implementation and enhance quality. This will be followed by another three TAs to 
increase  capacity  in  infrastructure  sectors,  including  roads.  For  the  Project,  the  Project 
Management Unit (PMU) established under the previous road project will be expanded and 
strengthened to carry out the Project. One technical staff financed by the Project will be added 
and  a  total  of  212  person-months  of  international  and  domestic  consulting  services  for 
construction supervision will be provided to ensure timely project implementation and quality. 
23.  External Assistance. External assistance has mainly been provided by the Government 
of Japan, EU, and ADB. Since 2000, the Government of Japan has provided grants totaling 
$34.6 million to transport; 54% to the road sector for roads improvement, project studies, and 
training. The ongoing Dili to Suai road rehabilitation project is adjacent to the Project. The EU 
approved a grant of $7.6 million in May 2004 to finance rehabilitation of five bridges on the 
alignment from Viqueque to Uatucarbau, which is included as one of the road sections under the 
Project.  Since  2000,  ADB  has  provided  two  TAs  to  transport  totaling  $1.5  million.  It  has 
administered two emergency infrastructure rehabilitation projects (EIRPs) funded by the Trust 
Fund for East Timor. The first EIRP was a multisector project covering the road, port, and power 
sectors. The total grant was $29.8 million; 80% was applied to roads. It aimed to facilitate peace 
and security, and humanitarian relief aid by addressing immediate system failures. The second 
EIRP, with a grant of $9 million entirely for roads, is ongoing and expected to be completed in 
2007. A summary of external assistance to the sector is presented in Appendix 2. 
24.  Lessons Learned. Several lessons can be drawn from the experience of administering 
the EIRPs. First, as emergency needs are abated, more attention and efforts should be given to 
quality and sustainability. Second, project design needs to take into account the limited capacity 
of MPW (the Executing Agency) to undertake technical design, procure goods and services, 
monitor and supervise rehabilitation, and manage contracts. Third, a well-staffed functional 
PMU is critical for project implementation and needs to be put in place at project onset.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
25.  The Project is expected to contribute to economic growth and poverty reduction by 
improving road transport in the project area. It will (i) improve accessibility for residents in the 
project area to food, economic opportunities, and social services; (ii) promote private sector-led 
industrial and agricultural development; (iii) foster market formation, and facilitate domestic and 
international trade; and (iv) generate income and employment opportunities. The outcome will 
be improved road infrastructure for economic and social development.  
B.  Outputs 
26.  The Project will produce the following outputs: (i) rehabilitation and improvement of 
about 123 km of core network roads; (ii) labor-intensive routine road maintenance for 45 km; 
(iii) sound and sustainable road maintenance policies; (iv) an efficient bidding and contracting 
system  for  engaging  communities  in  road  maintenance  through  local  small  contractors; 
(v) improved  project  management,  supervision,  and  monitoring;  and  (vi)  identification  of 
modalities to ensure community-based, gender-inclusive rehabilitation and maintenance of rural 
feeder roads. Project activities include 
 
(i)  rehabilitation  of  three  road  sections  to  fair  conditions:  (a)  Oeleu–Zumalai 
(35.9 km), (b) Aituto–Same (30.8 km), and (c) Viqueque–Uatucarbau (55.8 km), 
by strengthening the base, resurfacing, protecting and stabilizing slopes, and 
improving drainage system and shoulders; 
(ii)  routine maintenance for Iliomar–Lospalos (45 km), to be implemented by small 
local contractors using labor-intensive methods, and include patching, improving 
side drains, repairing culverts, improving shoulders, constructing lined drains, 
and bioengineering;4 
(iii)  international  and  domestic  consulting  services  for  project  management, 
construction  supervision,  establishment  of  road  maintenance  policies,  road 
maintenance training and supervision, and socioeconomic impact monitoring; 
and  
(iv)  community empowerment initiatives, including (a) identification of community-
based and gender-inclusive modalities for rehabilitation and maintenance of rural 
feeder roads adjacent to the project roads; (b) HIV/AIDS prevention and road 
safety awareness programs along the project roads to be implemented by an 
international  NGO  with  expertise  in  community-based  and  labor-intensive 
infrastructure development and service delivery in one selected subdistrict along 
the project roads; and (c) monitoring of employment targets for women.

2.  Prioritization of Road Investments 
28.  Rehabilitating and maintaining an extensive road network requires sizeable investment. 
Given  the  constraints  of  financial  resources  and  institutional  capacity,  prioritizing  road 
investments to maximize economic and social benefits is crucial. 
29.  To  define  the  project  scope  and  develop  a  medium-  to  long-term  road  investment 
program, 1,650 km of the core road network and relevant district roads were surveyed and 
traffic counts carried out at 30 locations across the country. Based on the road characteristics 
and conditions, traffic volume, and proposed interventions, rigorous economic analyses were 
conducted, using the highway design and management model (HDM-4) (a model for searching 
for an optimum combination of investments and interventions for the road sector) developed 
jointly by the World Bank and ADB, among others, to identify road interventions that give the 
best economic net present values with least-cost investments. The three roads, comprising five 
road sections to be financed by the Project, top the list in terms of economic net present value. 
30.  The 5–10-year prioritized road investment program based on the economic analysis will 
give directions for future ADB assistance in the road sector, benefit aid coordination to ensure 
consistent road sector development planning, and serve as the basis for the Government’s own 
road sector investments. 
3.  Aid Coordination and Project Complementarity 
31.  In the process of selecting road sections for the Project, close consultations with aid 
agencies involved in the road sector, particularly the Japan International Cooperation Agency 
and EU, were conducted to maximize complementarities and avoid overlap. The Aituto–Same 
road connects to the Dili–Suai road, which is currently under repair funded by the Japan 
International  Cooperation  Agency.  Rehabilitation  of  the  Viqueque–Ilioma  road  section 
complements the EU’s bridge project, which is now at the design stage, and ensures that the 
whole road is in fair condition. The Project is also complementary to EIRP-2, which is repairing 
short damaged road sections from Maliana and Zumulai. 
4.  Road Safety and Sustainability  
32.  Road fatalities in Timor-Leste are among the highest in southeast and south Asian 
countries with more than 20 deaths per 10,000 vehicles. The potential for even greater accident 
rates is high, considering the increase in vehicles, growing population, and increased vehicle 
speeds resulting from improvements to the road network. However, data on traffic accidents and 
fatalities show that most occur in urban areas, and especially in Dili. A national road safety 
strategy was prepared, but implementation has not started. 
33.  Road  accidents  have  various  causes,  including  poor  road  design  standards,  driver 
behavior, and lack of awareness among villagers. Road widening and realignment are not

8 
justifiable at this stage due to demand constraints. The Project includes a pilot road safety 
awareness campaign program to be implemented by an NGO.  
34.  Road  sustainability  is  a  major  challenge.  This  is  not  mainly  because  of  financial 
constraints and difficult geographical conditions; but rather capacity constraints to establish road 
maintenance policies, and to plan, organize, and execute capital and maintenance works. The 
Government is expecting total revenues to be above $100 million per year for an indefinite 
period, and has committed about $190 million from the budget for road maintenance during the 
Project. In spite of growing capacity, spending the budget funds remains a challenge for the 
Government. The Project, through the routine road maintenance Iliomar–Lospalos component, 
will establish sound and sustainable road maintenance policies for the road sector and project 
roads, and institutionalize a bidding and contracting system for engaging local small contractors 
from communities in routine maintenance. This will help the Government continue with its own 
road maintenance investments and preserve road assets at low costs. 
5.  Labor-Intensive Maintenance 
35.  Road assets can be prevented from rapidly deteriorating if timely routine maintenance 
can be done. Routine road maintenance mainly involves clearing vegetation from shoulders, 
improving and shaping shoulders, clearing drains and culverts, and constructing stone masonry-
lined drains, which can be done by labor without heavy equipment. Labor-intensive routine 
maintenance will help extend the life of roads, and generate business opportunities and income 
for  local  communities.  Under  the  Project,  the  Lliomar–Lospalos  road  section,  which  is  in 
relatively good and maintainable condition, was selected for routine maintenance using labor-
intensive methods. The ten contract packages for the road will target small contractors from 
local communities. An international road maintenance specialist will be provided to train the 
local contractors, improve their maintenance skills, and ensure works are done properly. With 
the establishment of road maintenance policies, institutionalization of a bidding and contracting 
system for engaging local small contractors, and skill development, systematic labor-intensive 
road maintenance is expected in the future to preserve assets, while generating income and job 
opportunities. 
6.  Gender Inclusive Development 
36.  In light of women’s traditional exclusion from employment opportunities derived from 
road construction, the Project will support socioculturally sensitive modalities to ensure women’s 
involvement in road rehabilitation and maintenance. In this respect, MPW─through the PMU—
will encourage civil works contractors to increase the percentage of women workers to 30% of 
wage-laborers  (including  at  least  75%  of  bioengineering  activities).  The  community 
empowerment initiatives for sustainable rehabilitation and maintenance of selected rural feeder 
roads will have a strong gender focus and support a broad range of initiatives that include (i) 
participatory  and  gender-inclusive  identification  and  selection  of  rural  feeder  roads  to  be 
rehabilitated under the Project; and (ii) skills transfer to women in bioengineering, agroforestry, 
and agricultural extension, combined with literacy, nutrition, reproductive health, and HIV/AIDS 
prevention. The initiatives will include the design of sustainable modalities to ensure gender-
inclusive maintenance of rehabilitated feeder roads. 
7.  HIV/AIDS Prevention and Reproductive Health 
37.  Although  accurate data on HIV prevalence are not available, recent surveys jointly 
carried  out  by  MOH  and  the  World  Health  Organization  estimate  HIV  at  0.64%  of  the

9 
population.5 In light of the potential impact of road rehabilitation on the spread of HIV/AIDS, the 
Project will fund culturally sensitive and gender-responsive HIV/AIDS awareness and education 
initiatives  along  the  project  road;  and  target  high-risk  groups,  including  local  construction 
workers, long-distance drivers, and women in the campsites and in the corridors of influence 
along project roads. These initiatives—to be funded as part of the community empowerment 
initiatives (component 4)—will complement Government-led initiatives for HIV/AIDS prevention, 
be implemented in consultation with MOH and local government agencies, and are in line with 
the National Strategic Plan for a Comprehensive and Multi-Sectoral Response to HIV/AIDS and 
STI 2002–2005 (2002). 
8.  Institutional Capacity Development in the Road Sector 
38.  The ADB country strategy and program update for 2005-2006 identified institutional 
capacity development as central to all activities. Four infrastructure sector capacity development 
TAs are programmed, including one approved in July 2005 (footnote 3). The TA is designed to 
address infrastructure institutional issues across sectors; and the shortage of qualified road 
engineers to plan, execute, and supervise the road investment projects. The TA will train 60 
local individuals with some technical background, both from the Government and private sector.  
39.  Although the Project focuses on physical road infrastructure and its implementation, in 
light of the capacity-building TA, the Project will provide an ideal training ground for the trainees 
to practice what they have learned from the courses and acquire practical experience in project 
implementation, construction supervision, and contract management. The PMU has already 
produced a construction supervision guide and trained four Government officials by involving 
them in project implementation and supervision. With more technical people available, more 
staff can be trained by working with the PMU and international consulting team.  
9.  Stakeholder Participation and Consultation 
40.  Extensive  public  consultations  were  conducted  with  Government  officials; 
international/national NGOs involved in community-based infrastructure development, service 
delivery,  and  HIV/AIDS  prevention;  as  well  as  local  communities  in  the  project  area. 
Consultations aimed to plan and prioritize road investments, assess the potential impacts of 
proposed interventions, and mitigate associated adverse risks. A consultation workshop was 
successfully conducted on 7 March 2005. During road condition surveys of the national and 
district  road  network  and  socioeconomic  surveys,  the  TA  consulting  team  (footnote  1) 
conducted 10 key informant interviews with district administrators, district development officers, 
village (suco) and hamlet chiefs, and women’s groups and associations. Nine village focus 
group discussions were held. Sample surveys with households, vehicle operators, passengers, 
and freight shippers were conducted. In total, about 600 stakeholders were consulted. They 
showed keen interest in sharing their perceptions about the causes of poverty, approaches to 
poverty reduction, and potential impact of road improvements on the economic and social 
development of the villages. Road improvement ranked among the main priorities, which also 
include education, skill training, fertilizers, farming machines, and irrigation to increase farming 
productivity and the water supply system. Local community concerns were considered and 
reflected  in  the  project  design,  particularly  in  designing  the  community  empowerment 
component (Appendix 3).

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
54.  Traffic  forecasts  by  vehicle  type  and  type  of  traffic  (normal  and  generated)  were 
prepared for the project road sections for 20 years from 2005 to 2024. The forecasts are based 
on expected GDP growth and on the income elasticity for national transport demand in relation 
to GDP growth. According to the International Monetary Fund’s medium-term outlook for Timor-
Leste, GDP will grow at 5% per annum. Income elasticity of demand for normal traffic is 
estimated at 1.2. Therefore, growth for normal traffic is estimated at 6%. This applies to all types 
of  vehicles  and  is  justified,  given  the  lack  of  secondary  data  and  any  previous  studies. 
Generated traffic is assumed to represent 10% of normal traffic, adjusted for seasonal patterns.

14 
A conservative assumption is that no traffic will be generated on roads that are not in very poor 
overall condition. The traffic forecast for the project road sections is summarized in Appendix 8. 
55.  The economic analysis was carried out for the three project roads by comparing the 
with- and without-project scenarios using the highway design and management model (para. 
28). The economic analysis covers 20 years (2005–2024), based on a rehabilitation period of 1 
year starting in 2007. All benefits and costs are in constant 2005 prices. The economic prices 
are expressed using the world price numeraire. 
56.  The economic costs of the Project are (i) the capital cost, including labor, equipment and 
materials, consulting services, and physical contingency; and (ii) the costs of maintaining the 
project  roads.  The  economic  benefits  arise  from  (i)  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs, 
particularly repair costs, due to the improved road conditions; (ii) savings in maintenance costs; 
(iii) time savings for road users; and (iv) benefits to generated traffic. The Project will have other 
benefits, such as improved food security and access to economic and social services, which 
were not included in the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) calculation.  
57.  Using a 12% discount rate, the net present value is $6.85 million and the EIRR 24.1%. 
The vehicle operating cost savings account for the majority of the benefits (95% of the total). 
The results of the sensitivity analysis confirm the Project’s economic viability. The switching 
value6 for increased rehabilitation costs is determined to be 92%, and the switching value for 
decreased benefits 44%. In the worst case scenario—a combination of increased costs and 
decreased benefits—the net present value would be reduced to $3.42 million, and the EIRR to 
17.7%. Detailed economic analysis is in Appendix 9. 
V.  POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL IMPACTS 
A.  Poverty Reduction Impact 
58.  The Project will contribute to poverty reduction in the project area and the country by 
promoting  economic  growth  through  investment  and  road  infrastructure  improvement.  The 
extensive national, district, village, and hamlet surveys indicate that the Project will directly 
benefit  the  road  users,  such  as  rural  households,  passengers,  vehicle  operators,  freight 
shippers, traders, and the private sector as a whole. Many users, particularly poor users, are 
currently  suffering  from  high  transportation  costs,  while  vehicle  operators  and  owners 
experience high vehicle operating costs, including high vehicle repair costs. The Project is 
expected to benefit about 62,000 people, including 55,000 poor and 28,000 extremely poor.  
59.  The Project will reduce poverty by providing villagers in the project area with immediate 
income-generating  opportunities.  During  implementation,  about  500  person-years  of 
employment will be created. At its completion, the Project will contribute to a better livelihood for 
villagers by (i) providing mobility to isolated societies; (ii) easing access to market centers for 
food, education, and health services; (iii) promoting trading and hence cash crop cultivation; and 
(iv) reducing transport costs for the private sector as presented in Appendix 10.

communities  and  vulnerable  groups  were  analyzed.  This  was  done  through  a  stakeholder 
consultation workshop, key informant interviews in districts, subdistricts, villages (suco), and

61.  The gender division of labor and women’s traditional exclusion from the benefits derived 
from  road  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  works  were  clearly  identified  during  focus  group 
discussions with public works constructors. The Project will seek modalities to promote gender 
equality  and  women’s  greater  access  to  employment  opportunities  provided  by  road 
improvement by encouraging civil works contractors to (i) increase the percentage of women 
workers  to  30%  of  their  labor  force  (including  women’s  involvement  in  at  least  75%  of 
bioengineering activities), and (ii) carry out gender-sensitive HIV/AIDS prevention and road 
safety awareness in the project area. 
62.  Anecdotal evidence suggests an increase in the number of traffic accidents, with a 
continuing increasing trend as the road network is improved and overall traffic increases. The 
Project will carry out awareness campaigns for the local population in the project area (including 
vehicle operators as one target group) and safety education programs for school children. This 
awareness program will be accompanied by establishing checkpoints and posting warning signs 
at  the  entrance  of  each  residential  area  located  along  the  road  sections  to  be 
improved/maintained to slow down traffic passing through the area. 
63.  Other than the HIV/AIDS and traffic safety issues, the Project will have no adverse 
impact on vulnerable groups and no negative implication for indigenous people. No minority 
ethnic groups or indigenous population groups are found in the project area. No resettlement 
plan will be necessary as the Project will occur within the existing alignment or on land owned 
by the Government. 
C.  Environmental Impacts 
64.  The Project is classified as environmental category B, as all road improvement activities 
will  be  confined  to  existing  rights-of-way,  and  no  land  acquisition  or  resettlement  will  be 
required. Field surveys in the areas of roads selected for rehabilitation and improvement were 
conducted  to  assess  environmental  impacts  of  the  Project,  and  an  initial  environmental 
examination  (IEE)  was  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines 2003 the summary of which is presented in Appendix 11. The IEE findings support 
the overall category B (nonsensitive) classification for the Project. 
65.  The Project does not pass through protected areas and will have no impact on native 
fauna  and  flora.  The  construction  of  improved  drainage  structures,  stabilization  of  slopes 
through bioengineering, replanting of trees, and other measures undertaken by the Project will 
have long-term beneficial effects on the environment. The frequency and severity of landslides 
will be reduced along the project roads. The replanting of trees and native vegetation will 
stabilize the landscape, may help improve water quality, and will enhance scenic beauty.

66.  Short-term impacts will be unavoidable, such as traffic delays, noise, dust, and other 
temporary impacts such as loss of vegetation due to earth moving. These impacts will be 
directly related to rehabilitation operations and will end with the completion of rehabilitation. As a 
result, required mitigation measures are minor. Adherence to best engineering practices during 
the rehabilitation phase and strict enforcement of the environmental management plan (EMP) 
will avoid or adequately mitigate all of the rehabilitation-related impacts.   
D.  Project Risks 
67.  The design of the Project has taken into account potential risks associated with the 
project management and rehabilitation quality. The Project will maintain and expand the PMU 
established for EIRP-2 to strengthen its capacity so that it can handle greater responsibilities. A 
team of international and domestic consultants will be provided for construction supervision. A 
community empowerment program, dealing with road safety, HIV/AIDS, and other social risks, 
will be implemented by an NGO. Environmental impact will be monitored through construction 
supervision  and  mitigated  at  the  rehabilitation  stage  in  accordance  with  the  EMP.  Project 
sustainability will be enhanced by ensuring rehabilitation quality, training Government officials, 
identifying low-cost maintenance modalities, and establishing maintenance policies for the road 
sector and project roads.

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 
A.  Road Network 
1.  Roads, the dominant mode of transport in Timor-Leste, carry about 70% of freight and 
90%  of  passenger  traffic.  The  road  network  is  dense  compared  with  other  countries  with 
comparable income levels. The total length of the road network is estimated at 6,040 kilometers 
(km), consisting of 1430 km of national roads linking district centers, 870 km of district roads, 
providing links to large administrative centers, and 720 km in Dili and several smaller regional 
towns. The remaining 3,020 km comprises rural access or feeder roads. Urban roads represent 
about 800 km and feeder/rural roads roughly 3,020 km. About 1,800 km of roads are paved, 
representing a relatively large part of the core network (84%). Almost 100% of the national 
roads are paved, and all were paved at some time. 
2.  The road network is strongly influenced by its spatial and physical environment. A main 
arterial road runs along the semiarid northern coast, serving the economic activity around Dili 
and trade connections by sea and to the west. Connections with the southern economic zone 
cross a mountainous and midland area, which includes steep lands of unstable rock and poor 
soils  that  are  highly  susceptible  to  erosion  and  landslides.  Most  of  the  north–south  road 
connections are impassable year-round at this time. The southern coastal zone, which has 
higher population density, agricultural production, and energy reserves, has a moisture climate 
and comprises alluvial formations and numerous rivers which are prone to changing course 
during the monsoon. The network is thus vulnerable to natural hazards of erosion and flooding, 
and access is frequently cut at high-risk locations during the wet season and frequently remains 
impassable during the dry season. The terrain and low standard of roads limit the support 
provided to the economy in the south and midlands, such as coffee and agriculture, and soon 
energy resources. 
3.  The extensive road network was constructed with relatively low standards of design and 
materials. A pragmatic approach adapting to the often severe terrain conditions were obviously 
used,  resulting  in  a  very  low  horizontal  and  vertical  geometrical  standard  in  mountainous 
regions. The road widths appear to have been compromised according to the actual terrain 
conditions, resulting in many very narrow roads. While 100% of national roads and 71% of 
district roads were bitumen paved, shoulders are often constructed out of impervious earthen 
material. This, combined with the difficult geological conditions, torrential rains, and lack of 
maintenance, has caused rapid deterioration of the road system. Only 24% of national roads 
and 11% of district roads are currently in good condition. 
B.  Traffic Volume 
4.  Traffic volume is small and concentrated around Dili. Traffic counts in 2000 showed that 
one third of the road network outside urban centers carried more than 200 vehicles per day 
(with 15% carrying more than 500 vehicles per day, less than 2% carrying more than 1,000 
vehicles per day). One third of the network carried less than 50 vehicles per day. Traffic counts 
conducted in 2005 suggest that the average daily traffic for motorized vehicles is about 160 on 
national roads, 90 on district roads, 30 on rural roads, and 170 on urban roads. The heaviest 
traffic flows, in excess of 400 vehicles per day, are on the northern coastal road. 
5.  The truck fleet consists almost entirely of light and medium-sized trucks, due to the 
narrow winding mountainous roads, which are hardly passable for large trucks. The traffic 
loading on the roads is generally very light, and is not the cause of the poor condition of the 
road network. This is evidenced by the fairly good shape of the payment structure in spite of a 
damaged and washed-out surface due to adverse weather conditions and lack of maintenance 
for more than a decade. In addition, the roads have little rutting—normally a sign of overloading.

C.  Transport Services 
6.  Walking is the most common mode of transportation, followed by small trucks and 
microbuses. Transport services are mainly provided by small-scale private companies, with one 
or two vehicles, and a small number of vehicle owner-operators. The Government has set 
minimum taxi fare rates, but has not set rates for passenger and freight buses and trucks. 
Drivers associations are apparently developing and setting rates. Passenger fares range from 
$0.50 to $3.00, depending on the distance, and average approximately $1.00 per one-way trip. 
This is high and not affordable for many rural people, particularly, the poor. On the other hand, 
the fares barely allow vehicle operators to achieve a decent living standard. Half of vehicle 
operators  and  owner-operators  are  estimated  to  be  living  below  the  national  poverty  line. 
Operating costs are high, with repair costs averaging about $1,500 per year. Nearly 50% of the 
total repair costs are caused by the poor road conditions. 
D.  Road Safety 
7.  Road fatalities are relatively high with more than 20 persons per 10,000 vehicles. A 
recent study of available data gathered at the National Dili Hospital shows that the total number 
of patients from road traffic accidents reached 2,728 or an average of 114 patients per month in 
2002 and 2003. There were 41 deaths for the same period or an average of 2 deaths per month 
associated with road traffic accidents. In 2003, 1,354 road traffic accident patients were treated 
at the emergency facility, accounting for 11% of all hospitalized patients in the same year. The 
potential for even greater accident rates is high, considering the increased number of vehicles, 
growing population, and increased vehicle speeds resulting from improvements to the road 
network. A national road safety strategy was prepared, but implementation has not started. 
E.  Institutional Framework 
8.  The Government has made great progress in establishing the institutions necessary to 
run the country. In the road sector, the Government has established much of the essential 
framework, including laws, institutions, and development plans. 
9.  In 2003, the Government introduced two laws to regulate and manage the road sector: 
(i) Basic Law for Vehicle Transport; and (ii) Road Code. The former covers rules and regulations 
governing  vehicle  registration,  road  charges,  passenger  and  freight  transport  services  and 
passenger fares, and planning and coordination of public infrastructure provision. The Road 
Code  covers  road  rules,  traffic  management,  classification  and  use  of  roads,  vehicle 
categorization, fines, vehicle emissions, accident reporting, and licensing of drivers.  
10.  The Directorate of Roads, Bridges, and Flood Control (DRBFC) of MPW is responsible 
for  the  provision  and  management  of  road  infrastructure.  It  operates  through  a  central 
administration and five regional offices (in, Baucau, Dili, Maliana, Oecussi and Same). The 
Directorate  of  Equipment  and  Materials  manages  equipment  owned  by  the  Government. 
DRBFC  has  12  staff  with  engineering  qualifications,  out  of  a  total  of  91.  Due  to  historic 
circumstances, DRBFC has a very limited capacity for strategic planning, project preparation 
and  implementation,  construction  supervision,  contract  management,  and  socioeconomic 
evaluation.  
F.  Government Vision and Strategy  
11.  The Government currently is faced with managing a degraded road network, which 
entails a very high cost for the reactive work needed to keep it functioning. The Government 
therefore has set a 10-year vision for the road system to accomplish the following:

13.  According to the Ministry of Planning and Finance, the Government is expecting total

H.  Main Issues and Challenges 
14.  The  Government  faces  a  number  of  challenges  with  respect  to  the  road  transport 
infrastructure.  The  challenges  relate  mainly  to  financing  and  capacity  of  planning  and 
implementing capital investment projects. Major issues include (i) rehabilitating roads in some 
locations, (ii) moving from a reactive to a preventive approach regarding infrastructure works, 
(iii) orienting road design standards and maintenance practices in a way to minimize life-cycle 
transport costs, (iv) developing sustainable arrangements for managing the rural road network, 
(v) addressing social impacts and involvement, (vi) providing additional resources and skills for 
DRBFC, and (vii) increasing spending levels to maintain the current road system.

Timor-Leste is one of the poorest countries in the world. With a population between 750,000 and 1 million. Gross

month or more per year. The literacy rate is around 40%; life expectancy is 57 years; and unemployment is high

the maternal mortality rate is 890 per 100,000 births. Malnutrition is rife with 3–4% of children aged 6 months to 5

The focus of the Project on the rehabilitation and maintenance of national roads matches the priorities set forth by the 
Government in the national development plan. The entire road network, from feeder roads to national roads, is quickly 
deteriorating and impassable at many points. The key element is to save the national road network, and then 
sequence improvements to district and rural feeder roads so that farmers are able to reach markets, and industries to 
choose locations based on nontransport factors, such as availability of local labor and natural resources. The key 
objective is to ensure connectivity between urban areas and agricultural production centers, ports, and markets. While 
contributing to the overarching goal of poverty reduction, the rehabilitation of national roads should be complemented 
by a long-term strategy to ensure connectivity between national, district, and rural feeder roads, and cost-effective 
modalities to ensure sustainable rehabilitation and maintenance of rural feeder roads.

A detailed poverty impact assessment (PIA) and social analysis were conducted during the project preparatory 
technical assistance (TA). The TA consultants (i) held a stakeholder consultation workshop, key informant interviews,

Project’s benefits from being passed on to the poor. The PIA also distributed the economic net benefits among 
different stakeholder groups, which include (i) poor, very poor, and non-poor passengers; (ii) vehicle operators and

connectivity will allow residents of this region to have access to health care and educational services. 
 
The social analysis analyzed the profile of local villages and villagers’ perspectives on poverty and causes of poverty,

C.  Description of the Environment 
  1.  Physical Resources 
5.  Timor-Leste comprised the eastern end of the island of Timor, plus the enclave territory 
of Oecusi and the islands of Atauro and Jaco; this amounts to a land area of about 14,609 
square kilometers. Timor is the easternmost of the Lesser Sunda islands, lying from 8–10 
degrees south of the equator and about 500 km north of Australia.2 The country has a dramatic 
and mountainous topography, dominated by the Ramelau Mountains stretching across the 
middle of the island from the eastern to the western tip.  
6.  The island is unique among the major islands of the Sunda archipelago in that it is not of 
volcanic  origin,  but  is  a  continental  fragment,  composed  largely  of  limestone  and  other 
sedimentary deposits. The island is geologically young, with steep and unstable slopes and 
deep valleys, prone to flash floods. More than 40% of the land area is estimated to have a slope 
of greater than 40%3. The steep topography and torrential rains result in thin and unstable soils, 
with low water-holding capacity (footnote 2). Occasionally deeper soils may be found on the 
coastal and inland plains.  
7.  The climate is hot and humid tropical, with large variations in rainfall and temperature 
over short distances due to the steep topography. Broadly speaking two annual seasons are 
determined  by  the  monsoon,  which  varies  in  length  according  to  location.  Timor-Leste  is 
significantly drier than the other islands in the archipelago. The Ramelau Mountain ridge forms 
the main watershed in the country and is the source of all major streams. Even with more than 
100 rivers, surface water is scarce, as most rivers are not perennial. The country has only one 
lake of significant size (Iralalaru lake in the east). Most water for domestic and agricultural use is 
obtained from streams and springs, with the exception of the eastern part of the country, where 
wells are fairly common.  
8.  Baseline  data  for  air  or  water  quality  is  lacking.  Given  that  the  country  is  very 
underdeveloped with almost no industrial infrastructure and very little vehicular traffic, air quality 
can be expected to be good overall. Despite the generally sparse traffic, vehicular emissions in 
urban areas may sometimes produce significant levels of pollution. The other major source of 
air pollution is smoke from the burning of wood as a cooking fuel.  
9.  The country has few water-polluting industries; the processing of coffee beans is the 
major  industrial  pollution  source.  Domestic  sewage  and  waste,  domesticated  animals,  and 
sedimentation due to soil erosion are the main causes of water pollution overall. The country

2.  Ecological Resources 
12.  Since  Timor-Leste  is  an  island,  fisheries  and  other  marine  resources  constitute  an 
important segment of the natural environment. Overall, the marine and coastal environments 
appear to be more intact here than on most other islands in the region. Overexploitation of the 
resource in general, and overfishing by commercial interests in particular, are not identified as 
problems at this point. Since the Project is not anticipated to impact the marine resources, these 
resources are not discussed in detail here. 
13.  Timor-Leste is situated east of the Wallace line and, therefore, has biological elements 
of both Asian and Australian origin. This creates the potential for unique species. However, no 
up-to-date information is available on the number or location of remaining native species, with a 
few exceptions regarding bird species. Nearly 200 species of mammals have been identified on 
the island, but their status today is poorly known. Much of the wildlife commonly seen today is 
feral domestics, such as cattle, buffalo, donkeys, and pigs. Native wildlife can only be seen in 
the more isolated forest areas (for example, deer, monkeys, civets, cuscus, and a variety of 
bat). Reptiles are very poorly described. Cobras, pythons, and crocodiles are said to inhabit the 
island, but nothing is known of their number or distribution (footnote 3). Both hunting and trading 
in protected species are prohibited under United Nations regulations, but both practices were 
observed during the project surveys. The Project will not affect any protected natural areas or 
ecologically isolated habitats, and no impacts are anticipated on native wildlife.  
14.  Numerous primary and secondary documentary sources describe massive deforestation 
in  recent  years,  and  this  was  confirmed  by  the  environmental  field  surveys.  Estimates  of 
clearing range as high as 90% of the original forest cover. Today the dominant vegetation 
across the island and within the project area is savannah/grassland, interspersed with shrubs 
and  occasional  stands  of  trees.  Most  lands  show  evidence  of  clearing  and  significant 
disturbance by human activities, especially slash-and-burn cultivation, and coffee growing and 
grazing, even on steep slopes. In the one project area where sizable stands of forest were 
observed (Road A08 Lospalos), the forest was definitely secondary rather than primary.  
15.  By far the most common ecosystems on the island are the grasslands and what Carter 
terms “regrowth communities.” Regrowth communities occur throughout landscapes that have 
been disturbed by slash-and-burn agriculture and by other rural land-clearing activities. “Where 
left unattended, regrowth communities range from simple herbaceous communities to areas 
with scattered bamboo, casuarinas, and eucalypts, and structurally more complex communities 
that include dense formations of shrubs, small trees, and creepers” (footnote 3). Field surveys

17.  The  island  has  15  protected  natural  areas  (PNAs).  The  PNAs  have  not  yet  been 
systematically  surveyed  due  to  the  Government’s  lack  of  personnel  and  funds.  Formal

3.  Economic Development 
18.  The population of Timor-Leste ranges from 750,000 to 1,000,000 and is young, with a 
median age of 20 years. Life expectancy at birth is 57 years, well below the average for east 
Asian and Pacific island countries. The population is predominately rural (75%). Timor-Leste 
has one of the least-developed economies in the region. The UNDP Human Development 
Index4 places Timor-Leste in the low human development category, ranking 158 among 177 
countries.  
19.  In late 1999, about 70% of the economic infrastructure of Timor-Leste was laid to waste 
by Indonesian troops and anti-independence militias; 260,000 people fled westward. Over the 
next 3 years, a massive international program, staffed by 5,000 peacekeepers (8,000 at peak) 
and 1,300 police officers, led to substantial reconstruction in both urban and rural areas. By mid-
2002, all but about 50,000 of the refugees had returned. Growth, however, was held back in 
2003 by extensive drought and the gradual winding down of the international presence. 
20.  As yet, no infrastructure supports tourism and virtually no industry exists. The agriculture 
sector is weak due to recently deficient monsoons, an inequitable land tenure system, and lack 
of education and training for farmers. Since roads provide the dominant form of transportation, 
the  lack  of  a  serviceable  road  infrastructure  contributes  significantly  to  the  prevalence  of 
poverty.  
21.  The  Project’s  poverty  impact  and  social  analyses  provide  a  detailed  description  of 
human and economic development, based on extensive field work.  
4.  Social and Cultural Resources 
22.  Timor-Leste is one of the poorest countries in the world. Project fieldwork indicates that 
as much as 88% of the population are poor, 46% are very poor. The improved roads that will 
result from the Project will benefit about 62,000 people. Of these, 55,000 are poor, and 28,000 
are  very  poor.  More  detailed  information  on  socioeconomic  values,  public  health,  cultural 
values,  and  quality  of  life  values  are  provided  in  the  Project’s  poverty  impact  and  social 
analyses. No indigenous peoples live in the country.  
23.  As yet, no official listing is available for historical and archaeological sites, although the 
Government has plans to undertake a survey when possible. Within the project area no sites of 
clearly archaeological or historical significance were noted.

D.  Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
26.  Overall, the Project’s beneficial impacts to people and the environment will substantially 
outweigh the adverse impacts, provided that best engineering practices are followed and the 
EMP is effectively implemented. Impacts on environmental, cultural, and human resources are 
identified in the respective sections of this SIEE. Those impacts are summarized here.  
27.  Erosion of soil and sedimentation of waterways are two of the most pervasive impacts 
from road rehabilitation projects. Sediment deposition and suspension in water courses have 
direct, negative impacts on water quality and aquatic ecosystems. Soil loss and redeposit can 
also adversely affect residential and agricultural properties. A related set of impacts are loss of 
native vegetation and the opening of habitats to the invasion of weeds. These impacts can be 
substantially mitigated or avoided altogether by implementing engineering best practices and 
bioengineering. Restricting earth-moving and clearing activities to the dry season will likewise 
greatly reduce the potential adverse impacts of road rehabilitation. 
28.  The potential reduction in water quality is a concern. Prevention of erosion and proper 
handling of sediment will largely prevent any reduction in water quality due to added sediment 
load. Proper storage, handling, and disposal of potential contaminants (such as fuels, lubricants, 
and solvents) will generally provide adequate protection of water quality from these potential 
sources of contamination. The waste and runoff from encampments must also be handled in 
accordance with the EMP to prevent adverse impacts on water quality. 
29.  Quarrying  and  extraction  of  construction  materials  must  be  strictly  regulated  in 
accordance  with  Government  guidelines  and  the  EMP,  to  avoid  such  adverse  impacts  as 
reduced  water  quality,  destruction  of  aesthetic  values,  and  creation  of  a  long-term  safety 
hazard.  
30.  The siting of encampments will be a critical issue. Encampments must be situated so 
that they do not seriously degrade the natural or social environment. Waste and effluent from 
encampments must be contained and disposed of safely, away from water courses, wells, and 
dwellings. 
31.  Disruption and delay of traffic plus the generation of noise, vibration, and dust are 
impacts that will be particularly noticeable to the local population. Asphalt mixing plants may 
produce a significant amount of air pollution. These impacts cannot be entirely avoided, as they 
are part of the nature of a construction project. However, they are temporary and can be greatly 
mitigated  through  proper  planning  and  scheduling,  proper  maintenance  of  equipment,  and 
following the EMP.  
32.  The majority of potentially adverse impacts are temporary and will cease with the end of 
project construction. Provided that proper maintenance is given to the roads throughout their 
operational life, no significant adverse impacts will result from the existence and operation of the 
roads themselves. Maintenance activities will produce minor impacts, but these are manageable

2.  Environmental Monitoring Plan 
36.  The  provisions  of  the  EMP  are  designed  to  avoid  adverse  environmental  impacts 
wherever  possible  and  to  mitigate  adverse  effects  to  an  acceptable  level  where  complete 
avoidance is not feasible. Enforcement of the EMP will be the responsibility of the international 
environmental inspector, acting on behalf of the PMU. The international inspector will work with 
the respective contractors’ environmental specialists and will have direct access to the PMU 
manager to resolve problems.  
37.  The EMP requires routine monitoring of air and water quality, noise levels, and waste 
management  throughout  the  construction  phase  of  the  Project.  Sampling  locations  and 
frequencies are designed to ensure that no significant degradations of quality of life indicators 
occur, especially near population centers. Proper selection and prior approval will be required 
for the location of staging areas, encampments, and building materials extraction sites. Earth-
moving activities will be restricted to the dry season to minimize siltation. The movement of 
construction-related vehicles will be routinely monitored to minimize disturbance to vegetation, 
and cleared areas will be reseeded promptly.

G.  Findings, Recommendations, and Conclusion 
43.  The three project roads were surveyed by a team of environmental specialists. There is 
no undisturbed habitat in the project impact area. Road A08 between Iliomar and Lospalos 
passes through secondary forest. Within the forest, no general tree cutting will occur; selected 
trees will be removed only where absolutely necessary to maintain safety standards for the 
road. Provided the requirements of the EMP are met, to mitigate potentially adverse impacts 
during project construction, no significant or long-term impacts will be made on the forested 
area, and no additional or special studies are needed. A replanting program will replace cut 
trees. The Project will not affect any PNAs or registered cultural/historical sites.  
44.  Overall,  the  project  area  has  been  subjected  to  long-term,  intense  agricultural  and 
grazing activities. The lands in the vicinity of the project roads have been heavily disturbed. 
Slash-and-burn agricultural techniques and the grazing of domesticated animals are common 
throughout the project area. Many areas are nearly devoid of vegetation cover from overgrazing. 
This environment is dominated by introduced or weedy species of plants and by domesticated 
species of animals, and is generally not able to support native fauna species. No known species 
of endangered plants or animals are found in the project area. 
45.  Residential areas are found along all three project roads. No habitations are within the 
existing right-of-way, and no involuntary relocation of residents is required. Short-term adverse 
impacts on habitations during project construction are primarily noise, vibration, and increased 
dust.  Careful  adherence  to  the  specifications  of  the  EMP  will  adequately  mitigate  these

construction-related impacts. The Project will have no long-term adverse impacts on the local 
society  and  no  negative  implications  for  vulnerable  groups.  No  minority  ethnic  groups  or 
indigenous population groups live in the project area.   
46.  The construction of improved drainage structures, stabilization of slopes, replanting of 
the right-of-way with a proper mix of native species, and other similar measures undertaken by 
the  Project  will  have  long-term  beneficial  effects  on  the  environment.  The  frequency  and 
severity of landslides will be reduced along the project roads. The replanting of trees and native 
vegetation will stabilize the landscape, may help improve water quality, and will enhance scenic 
beauty. The greatly improved ability of the population to move from place to place and to access 
much-needed social services will be a substantial and long-term enhancement. The overall, 
long-term effect of the Project on society will be to generate employment and improve access to 
markets  and  social  services.  The  potential  for  economic  growth  and  income-generating 
opportunities, expected impact on poverty reduction, and enhanced overall connectivity of the 
core road network will promote sustainable economic and social growth.  
47.  The findings of the IEE confirm that this Project be designated as ADB environmental

contact between the Ministry of Development and Environment, the construction supervision
